quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Raising Exceptions[/h1]

You can raise exceptions by using the [b]raise [/b]statement.  [code format="py" codeId="349"]print(1)
[b]raise ValueError[/b]
print(2)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
1
ValueError
>>>[/code]
[note]You need to specify the [b]type [/b]of the exception raised.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to raise a ValueError exception, if the input is negative.
[!raw!]
num = input(":")
if float(num) {0} 0:
  {1} ValueError("Negative!")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Raising Exceptions[/h1]

Exceptions can be raised with arguments that give detail about them.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="350"]name = "123"
[b]raise [/b]NameError("Invalid name!")[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
NameError: Invalid name!
>>>[/code]

quizzes.question: Can you use the raise statement outside the except block?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Raising Exceptions[/h1]

In [b]except [/b]blocks, the [b]raise [/b]statement can be used without arguments to re-raise whatever exception occurred.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="351"]try:
   num = 5 / 0
except:
   print("An error occurred")
   [b]raise[/b][/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
An error occurred

ZeroDivisionError: division by zero
>>>[/code]
